Cladding Bethanien Berlin Þiljur Bethanien Berlin The work "Cladding" was installed at Kunstquartier Bethanien in Berlin in 2002. This piece continues Magnús Pálsson's ongoing investigation into the acoustics and material presence of space.

"Þiljur" refers to panels or walls, and the work often manifests as a large-scale installation where the reflection of sound and the audience's spatial experience are central. Magnús Pálsson employs simple materials and industrial elements to create a complex experience where the viewer becomes an active participant in the formation of sound and space. By erecting these panels, which function as both barriers and reflective surfaces, the artist redefines the relationship between the artwork, the exhibition space, and the observer. Verkið "Þiljur" var sett upp í Kunstquartier Bethanien í Berlín árið 2002. Verkið heldur áfram rannsókn Magnúsar Pálssonar á hljóðvist og efniskennd rýmisins.

"Þiljur" vísa til þilja, eða veggja, og verkið felst oft í stórri innsetningu þar sem endurvarp hljóðs og rýmisupplifun gesta er í forgrunni. Magnús Pálsson notar einföld efni og iðnaðarhluti til að skapa flókna reynslu þar sem áhorfandinn er virkur þátttakandi í myndun hljóðs og rýmis. Með því að stilla upp þiljum, sem virka sem bæði hindranir og endurvarpsfletir, endurskilgreinir listamaðurinn samhengið milli verks, rýmis og áhorfanda. 2002 installation berlin sound acoustics mixed media installation blandað efni innsetning Þiljur (Cladding) Þiljur Kunstquartier Bethanien Kunstquartier Bethanien Berlin, Germany Installation view at Kunstquartier Bethanien Innsetningin í Kunstquartier Bethanien Wall text detail Nánari mynd af veggtext Floor text detail Nánari mynd af gólftext Installation with lighting Innsetningin með lýsingu

searchableContent.title: Cladding (Þiljur)
searchableContent.snippet: The work "Þiljur" (Cladding) is a large-scale installation comprising three panels situated in the entrance hall of the Anatomy Department at the U...
searchableContent.content:
Cladding (Þiljur) Þiljur The work "Þiljur" (Cladding) is a large-scale installation comprising three panels situated in the entrance hall of the Anatomy Department at the University of Iceland (Læknagarður). The work integrates pagan Norse mythology with scientific anatomy.

The core concept is the creation myth from Snorri Sturluson's Edda, detailing how the sky and earth were formed from the body of the giant Ymir. The text inscribed on the panels describes how the Earth was made from Ymir's flesh, the sea and waterways from his blood, the cliffs and mountains from his bones, the sky was created from his skull, and the clouds were formed from his brain.

Since the work was created for a medical institution, the creation myth and the description of Ymir's body parts are juxtaposed with anatomical terms in Icelandic. These terms are drawn from the glossary compiled by Guðmundur Hannesson, a professor of medicine in the early 20th century, who translated Latin anatomical terms into Icelandic. Magnús Pálsson notes that Hannesson's imaginative use of the Icelandic language creates such "beauty that it could be called poetry".

The text is carved and written into wood using various computer typefaces. Verkið "Þiljur" er stór innsetning sem samanstendur af þremur þiljum í anddyri Líffærafræðistofnunar Háskóla Íslands (Læknagarði). Verkið vinnur með sameiningu heiðinnar norrænnar goðafræði og vísindalegrar líffærafræði.

Grunnhugmyndin er sköpunarsagan úr Eddu Snorra Sturlusonar, þar sem himinn og jörð eru sköpuð úr líkama jötunsins Ýmis. Verkinu er ætlað að sýna hvernig jörðin varð til af holdi Ýmis, sær og votnin af blóði hans, björgin af beinunum, himinninn var gerður úr hausi hans, og skýin voru sköpuð úr heila hans.

Þar sem verkið er gert fyrir vísindastofnun eru sköpunarsagan og lýsingar á líkamshlutum Ýmis tengdar líffærafræðilegum heitum á íslensku. Þessi heiti eru fengin úr orðalista Guðmundar Hannessonar, prófessors í læknisfræði á fyrri hluta 20. aldar, sem þýddi latnesk líffæraheiti yfir á íslensku. Listamaðurinn segir að þessi þýðing Guðmundar sé „slíkrar fegurðar að það megi kallast ljóð".

searchableContent.title: Dispute Pole (Þrætubálkur)
searchableContent.snippet: "Þrætubálkur" (Dispute Pole) is a sound sculpture by Magnús Pálsson exploring communication, conflict, and acoustics within a defined space. The wo...
searchableContent.content:
Dispute Pole (Þrætubálkur) Þrætubálkur "Þrætubálkur" (Dispute Pole) is a sound sculpture by Magnús Pálsson exploring communication, conflict, and acoustics within a defined space. The work directly references Homer's Iliad, using Sveinbjörn Egilsson's translation with specific alterations by Steinar Sigurjónsson.

The work was produced in the Multimedia Department of the Icelandic College of Arts and Crafts (MHÍ) and performed by its students. Part 1 (Blót/Sacrifice) focuses on the Greek siege of Troy, where both armies call upon the gods for aid in the war. The sound performance features choirs of men and women, with the prayers delivered by students.

The images of the work on the website are taken from its exhibition at The Living Art Museum (Nýlistasafnið) at Vatnsstíg in Reykjavík. By translating the ancient dispute of the Iliad into a contemporary installation, Magnús creates a space where the viewer becomes part of the echoing narrative and conflict. "Þrætubálkur" er hljóðskúlptúr eftir Magnús Pálsson sem byggir á samskiptum, átökum og hljóðvist innan rýmis. Verkið tekur beinan mið af Ílíonskviðu Hómers, notast er við þýðingu Sveinbjarnar Egilssonar með ákveðnum breytingum eftir Steinar Sigurjónsson.

Verkið var unnið í Fjöltæknideild Myndlista- og handíðaskóla Íslands (MHÍ) og flutt af nemendum deildarinnar. Fyrsti þátturinn (Blót) snýst um umsátur Grikkja um Tróuborg, þar sem báðir herir ákalla guðina til fulltingis í stríðinu. Hljóðsetningin var flutt af kórum karla og kvenna og bænin flutt af nemendum.

Myndir af verkinu á vefsíðunni eru teknar þegar það var sýnt í Nýlistasafninu (NÝLÓ) á Vatnsstíg. searchableContent.title: Three Spells (Þrígaldur þursavænn)
searchableContent.snippet: "Þrígaldur (Þursavænn)" (Three Spells / Giant's Waft) is a complex installation by Magnús Pálsson that deals with the imperfection of video recordi...
searchableContent.content:
Three Spells (Þrígaldur þursavænn) Þrígaldur (Þursavænn) "Þrígaldur (Þursavænn)" (Three Spells / Giant's Waft) is a complex installation by Magnús Pálsson that deals with the imperfection of video recording and listening. The artist deliberately divides the space and transforms it through sound.

The work is related to the artist's use of video footage and elements from spaces he has utilized or has been put in charge of. It is described as a dramaturgical performance set up in Hafnarhús: ordinary floor sculptures and a rescue boat in the hall are performances that open the space to the outside sphere, through doors. This circulation acts as a technical supplement – deus ex machina.

Magnús utilizes a video perspective that shows a person, another reality, that disrupts the familiar approach and rushes into the whole picture with an unexpected experience. He shifts the videos so they replace computer language, or the internet, urging us to listen to sounds in plaster walls. The artist points out that nothing is fully perfect, as video recordings are inherently imperfect. "Þrígaldur (Þursavænn)" er flókin innsetning sem vinnur með ófullkomleika vídeóupptöku og hlustunar. Magnús Pálsson beitir sér fyrir því að skipta rýminu upp og umbreyta því með hljóði.

Verkið er hluti af vinnu listamannsins með vídeóum og hlutum úr rými sem hann hefur notað eða hefur verið umráðalaus um. Þetta er lýst sem leikrænni gjörningi sem var settur upp í Hafnarhúsinu: venjulegum skólflúrum og björgunarbátar í salnum eru gjörningar sem opna rýmið á ytra sviði, en gegnum hurðir. Þessi hringrás virkar sem tæknilegt viðbót – deus ex machina.

Magnús notar sjónarhorn í vídeóinu sem sýnir manneskju, annan veruleika, sem skekur til nálgunina og ryðst inn í heildarmyndina með óvæntri upplifun. Hann færir vídeóin svo þau skipta út tölvumáli, eða veraldarvefinum, og fær okkur til að hlusta á hljóð í gipsveggjum. Listamaðurinn er að benda á að ekkert sé fullkomið, þar sem vídeóupptökur eru í eðli sínu ófullkomnar. 2013 installation sound video space imperfection video sound mixed media vídeó hljóð blandað efni Þrígaldur þursavænn view 1 Exhibition catalog front page Forsíða sýningarskrár Þrígaldur þursavænn view 3 Þrígaldur þursavænn view 4 Þrígaldur þursavænn view 5 Þrígaldur þursavænn view 6 Catalog text page 1 (Icelandic) Sýningarskrá bls. 1 Catalog text page 2 by Halldór Björn Runólfsson Sýningarskrá bls. 2 eftir Halldór Björn Runólfsson

searchableContent.snippet: The work "Walking on Water" directly references the mythological idea of transcendental movement. Magnús Pálsson utilizes this concept to investiga...
searchableContent.content:
Walking on Water Gengið á vatni The work "Walking on Water" directly references the mythological idea of transcendental movement. Magnús Pálsson utilizes this concept to investigate materiality, gravity, and perception through an innovative arrangement.

The installation may involve creating a surface of water or a water reflection in an unexpected location within the space. By simply objectifying the impossible, the artist prompts the viewer to question the limitations of physics.

The work was exhibited at Kling & Bang in March 2012, accompanied by a performance called "Spud". This emphasizes the movement itself and the physical experience of the artist or participant in the face of the impossible. The performance transforms the work from a static sculpture into a living reflection on faith, power, and perception. Verkið "Gengið á vatni" vísar beint til hinnar goðsögulegu hugmyndar um yfirskilvitlega hreyfingu. Magnús Pálsson notar þessa hugmynd til að kanna efniskennd, þyngdarafl og skynjun með nýstárlegri uppsetningu.

Innsetningin getur falist í því að skapa yfirborð vatns eða endurkast vatns á óvæntum stað í rýminu. Með þessari einföldu hlutgervingu hið ómögulega, fær listamaðurinn áhorfandann til að spyrja sig um takmarkanir eðlisfræðinnar.

Verkið var sýnt í Kling & Bang í mars 2012, ásamt gjörningi sem nefndist "Spud". Þetta leggur áherslu á hreyfinguna sjálfa og líkamlega reynslu listamannsins eða þátttakandans andspænis hinu ómögulega. searchableContent.title: Paper love
searchableContent.snippet: Magnús's first book work, created in 1966 before most artists - Icelandic or international - had begun working with artist books. Pappírsást is a s...
searchableContent.content:
Paper love Pappírsást Magnús's first book work, created in 1966 before most artists - Icelandic or international - had begun working with artist books. Pappírsást is a sculptural bookwork in 4 copies, each a variation on the same concept. In one copy, the first page was folded over the irregularities of the cover page, then the next page folded over the first, and so on until the irregularities flattened out.

Bookwork. Positive and negative space. Each page conforms to the distorted shape of the adjacent page.

The interplay between the space delimited by the form of the object (internal space) and the space outside the object which the object shapes and delimits (external space). Both types of space belong to the same, continuous space.

Reference: Gunnar Harðarson, "Trönurnar fljúga - Um bókagerð íslenskra myndlistarmanna", Tímarit Máls og menningar, 1985. Fyrsta bókverk Magnúsar, frá 1966, þ.e.a.s. áður en meginþorri listamanna, erlendra sem innlendra, var tekinn til við bókagerð. Pappírsást er einskonar skúlptúrverk í 4 eintökum, sem hvert er tilbrigði við sömu hugmynd. Eitt eintakið var t.d. gert þannig að fyrsta blað bókarinnar var brotið yfir ójöfnur á kápublaðinu og næsta blað síðan brotið við fyrsta blaðið og svo koll af kolli uns ójöfnunar flöttust út.

Bókverk.  Jákvætt (pósitíft) og neikvætt rými.  Hver síða lagar sig að afmynduðu formi nærliggjandi síðu. 
Samspil þess rýmis sem afmarkast af formi hlutarins (innra rými) og þess rýmis sem er utan hlutarins en sem hluturinn formar og afmarkar (ytra rými). Báðar tegundir rýmis teljast til sama, samfellda rýmisins.

searchableContent.snippet: The work Darkness / Sunlight is a photographic or plaster piece from 1977 and exemplifies how Magnús Pálsson translated his philosophy of positive ...
searchableContent.content: Myrkur / Sólskin (Darkness / Sunlight) Myrkur / Sólskin The work Darkness / Sunlight is a photographic or plaster piece from 1977 and exemplifies how Magnús Pálsson translated his philosophy of positive and negative space into immaterial opposites. The work demonstrates Magnús's fundamental belief in positive and negative truth. The title directly references Magnús's core thinking: "...if one proposition is true, then the opposite proposition is equally true, isn't it? (...) yes, because no thing exists without its opposite also existing." Conceptual Execution The work is often presented as two plaster blocks that together form a spatial landscape. One block may represent the positive truth (e.g., Sunlight), and the other the negative truth (e.g., Darkness). By displaying these opposites side-by-side, Magnús emphasizes that the contradictions are mutually defining and are inseparable parts of the whole. The work is thus a continued investigation into the invisible space and how it is shaped by opposing forces. Verkið Myrkur / Sólskin er ljósmynda- eða gifsverk frá 1977 og er dæmi um hvernig Magnús Pálsson færði hugmyndafræði sína um jákvætt og neikvætt rými yfir í ósýnilegar andstæður. Verkið sýnir fram á grundvallarhugsun Magnúsar um jákvæðan og neikvæðan sannleika. Titillinn vísar beint í kjarnahugsun Magnúsar: „...ef ein fullyrðing er sönn þá er andstæð fullyrðing jafnsönn, ekki satt? [...] enginn hlutur er til nema andstæðan sé til um leið." Framkvæmd Hugmyndarinnar Verkið er oft sýnt sem tvær gifsblokkir sem saman mynda landslagsrými. Önnur blokkin gæti táknað jákvæðan sannleika (t.d. Sólskin) og hin neikvæðan sannleika (t.d. Myrkur). Með því að sýna þessar andstæður hlið við hlið, leggur Magnús áherslu á að andstæðurnar mótist gagnkvæmt og séu óaðskiljanlegur hluti af heildinni. Verkið er áframhaldandi rannsókn á ósýnilega rýminu og hvernig það er mótað af andstæðum krafti. 1977 plaster sculpture conceptual positive-negative-space opposites 1970s plaster gifs SOMETHING from NOTHING – The Visual Realm of Magnús Pálsson (EITTHVAÐ úr ENGU – Myndheimur Magnúsar Pálssonar) Retrospective – Myndheimur: Eitthvað úr engu (The Visual Realm of Magnús Pálsson. searchableContent.content: Bestu stykkin Bestu stykkin Three surviving sculptures from a larger anti-art series of cloth figures called Frúöld, created in 1965 and exhibited at Magnús Pálsson's debut solo exhibition at Ásmundarsalur in 1967. Made by stuffing old cloths with paper, stiffening with glue and paint until hard, then removing the paper so the cloth figures could stand like empty skins. Created in the artist's Hvarf garage studio during 1965-1967, a converted rural space that was documented in October 1967 before being destroyed by fire. The ironic titles (allegedly suggested by Dieter Roth) were inversely related to their visual appeal - the most miserable-looking was called 'The best piece,' with titles descending in flattery as the works became more visually interesting. The Frúöld were not well received; the public called them ugly and idiotic, questioning Pálsson's sanity. In response, he gathered the remaining pieces, piled them under the stairway to SÚM exhibition space on Vatnsstígur, poured concrete over them, and let them decompose. Only three survive in the Living Art Museum collection. The work exemplifies Pálsson's anti-art philosophy - childishly simple in concept, executed without traditional artistry, and deliberately unaesthetic, challenging Icelandic art's boundaries alongside contemporaneous provocations like the rye bread pile on Skólavörðuholt and SÚM's infamous hay bale. searchableContent.content: Þyrlulending (Helicopter Landing) Þyrlulending (Helicopter Landing) Conceptual work measuring anticipation and mechanical intervention, titled 'Sekúndurnar þar til Sikorskýþyrlan snertir' (The Seconds Before the Sikorsky Helicopter Touches Down). This time-based sculpture captures the moment before the Coast Guard's helicopter lands, materializing the immaterial through three plaster forms arranged in a triangle on the floor. The forms are casts of the negative space between the helicopter's wheels and the ground, with different heights indicating temporal progression - the tail wheel, which lands last, is the highest. Time is here transformed into solid matter, exploring themes of anticipation, mechanical intervention, and the transformation of temporal experience into physical form. Exhibited at the Venice Biennale in 1980 where Pálsson represented Iceland. searchableContent.content: Ást í sundlaug (Love in a Pool) Ást í sundlaug Love in a Pool is an example of the plaster works that Magnús Pálsson created from the mid-1970s onwards, where he systematically worked to objectify the immaterial. Some of these works could be referred to as plaster casts of emotions. The work is a plaster cast of the space created between two people in intimate communication. Execution The work depicts the space formed by two faces that look at each other just above the surface of the water. Conceptual Basis The couple's love is symbolized by the space between their faces when they look each other in the eye. In this way, Magnús makes the intangible (the emotion or the positive space) visible and material in the artwork. This line of inquiry—objectifying space and emotion—began with his earliest experiments in plaster and paper, such as Pappírsást (Paper Love), which dealt with the space delimited by the object's form, and later led to his Vocal Sculptures. Ást í sundlaug er dæmi um þau gifsverk sem Magnús Pálsson skapaði frá miðjum áttunda áratugnum, þar sem hann vann markvisst að því að hlutgera hið óefniskennda. Sum þessara verka mætti kalla gifsafsteypur af tilfinningum. Verkið er gifsafsteypa af rýminu sem skapast á milli tveggja manneskja í nánum samskiptum. Framkvæmd Verkið sýnir rýmið sem myndast af tveimur andlitum sem snúa hvort að öðru rétt fyrir ofan vatnsborðið. Hugmyndafræði Ást parsins er táknuð með rýminu sem myndast á milli þeirra þegar þau horfast í augu. Þannig gerir Magnús hið óáþreifanlega (tilfinninguna eða jákvæða rýmið) sýnilegt og efnislegt í verkinu. searchableContent.content: Dalalæða (Valley Mist) Dalalæða Valley Mist is an example of Magnús Pálsson's plaster works from the mid-1970s, where he objectified immaterial phenomena. The work is a plaster cast of a valley mist in miniature and was created in Vatnsdalur. The work was exhibited at the Venice Biennale in 1980. In this piece, Magnús reversed the traditional approach: The Valley Mist: Is transposed into the positive form (the plaster cast). The Landscape (The Valley): Becomes the negative space or background. The diagram illustrates how the plaster cast was taken: the plaster base forms the positive texture of the mist lying over the hills that stick up through the mist. Magnús Pálsson's Description "Here is merely a model in 1:250 scale of this very romantic phenomenon which mostly occurs only on still summer evenings. Very low mist creeps up a valley from the sea, covering only the bottom so that even low hills stick their heads up through it... Very lovely." This work clearly demonstrates Magnús's philosophy that opposites (space versus form) are equally true and inseparable. Dalalæða er dæmi um gifsverk Magnúsar Pálssonar frá miðjum áttunda áratugnum, þar sem hann hlutgerir óefnisleg fyrirbæri. Verkið er gifsafsteypa af dalalæðu í smækkaðri mynd og er unnið í Vatnsdal. searchableContent.content: Engin glypir solina (OG) Engin glypir solina (OG) Multi-channel sound sculpture installation created in 1983, later exhibited at Gallery One-One on Skólavörðustígur in 1993. The work consists of several 'sound sculptures' (hljóðskúlptúrar) arranged in two separate rooms, playing simultaneously to create an immersive audio environment. Drawing from childhood memories and fragments of conversation, the piece features fragmented narratives, coughing, clearing throats, yawning, humming, repetitions, and various human sounds that evoke gatherings of adults from another time and place. The installation includes physical elements: under each speaker (four speakers per 'rjóður' or room, creating stereo sound) are piles of snuff tobacco and large paper noses, referencing multiple senses and providing visual cues for the audio content. Individual sound sculptures have characteristically Icelandic folk humor titles including 'Enginn gleypir sólina... (þó hann bryðji tunglið eins og fisk)', 'Mús og lús', 'Hér pissa ég', and 'Herra Túrpur Jónsson'. The work was created with seven actors, a director, and sound engineer, with its strength lying in the sound mixing that places the listener 'in the middle of the picture.' searchableContent.title: Erðanú borð (A Table, Is It Now!)
searchableContent.snippet: Erðanú borð is an early key work by Magnús Pálsson that exemplifies his approach to conceptual art, prioritizing the unconventional and unexpected....
searchableContent.content: Erðanú borð (A Table, Is It Now!) Erðanú borð Erðanú borð is an early key work by Magnús Pálsson that exemplifies his approach to conceptual art, prioritizing the unconventional and unexpected. Classified as a mixed media sculpture, the piece is constructed from wood, metals, paper, and plaster. Pálsson was a pioneer of Fluxus art in Iceland. The work is an assembly of various materials and paper scraps, rendering it hardly usable as a table. This characteristic underscores the humor and playfulness that distinguish Magnús's style. The Story Behind the Title The title of the work originated from a direct interaction with the audience at its first exhibition in Ásmundarsalur. When a group of young boys approached the piece and asked in surprise, "What is this now?", Magnús simply replied, "This is a table." The boys responded with doubt and an exclamation: "Erðanú borð!" ("A Table, Is It Now!"). This phrase, which perfectly captures the absurdity and skepticism provoked by the work, became the official title of the piece. Ephemerality and the Autonomy of the Artwork Erðanú borð highlights not only Magnús's humor but also his approach to ephemerality and the idea that an artwork possesses an independent life and does not need to be eternal or solemn. When the work was first exhibited in Ásmundarsalur in 1968 (as seen in contemporary photographs), the base of the table was neat and intact. Subsequently, the piece was kept at the artist's home where it actively participated in the organic processes of its environment. Over the ensuing years, the bottom of the piece gradually frayed and changed, partly due to the interest of cats in the material that began to hang down. By allowing these unexpected changes to occur, without attempting to repair or "freeze" the work, Magnús underscored the artistic idea that chance and natural processes are legitimate components of the creation. This perfectly aligns with the principles of the Fluxus movement. The work is thus a living example that an artwork is allowed to change over time and that art does not always need to be rigid and solemn. Erðanú borð er eitt af fyrstu verkum Magnúsar Pálssonar sem sýnir dæmigerða nálgun hans á hugmyndalist, þar sem hann setur í forgang það sem er óhefðbundið og óvænt. Verkið er flokkað sem blönduð tækni og skúlptúr, unnið úr tré, málmum, pappír og gifsi. Magnús var einn af brautryðjendum Fluxus listar á Íslandi. Verkið er samsett úr alls konar efnisbútum og pappírsskræmum og er tæplega nothæft sem borð, sem undirstrikar húmorinn og glettni sem einkennir stílinn. Sagan á Bak Við Titilinn Titill verksins er tilkominn í beinum samskiptum við áhorfendur á fyrstu sýningu þess í Ásmundarsal. Þegar nokkrir ungir strákar komu að verkinu og spurðu forviða: "Hvað er nú þetta?", svaraði Magnús einfaldlega: "Þetta er borð." Drengirnir svöruðu þá með efa og upphrópun: "Erðanú borð!" Þetta svar, sem fangar þann fáránleika og efasemdir sem verkið vekur, varð síðan hið opinbera heiti á verkinu. Forgengileiki og Sjálfstætt Líf Verksins Erðanú borð lýsir ekki aðeins húmor Magnúsar heldur einnig nálgun hans á forgengileika og þá hugsun að listaverk eigi sjálfstætt líf og þurfi ekki að vera eilíf og hátíðleg. Þegar verkið var fyrst sýnt í Ásmundarsal árið 1968 (eins og sjá má á samtíma ljósmyndum) var botninn á borðinu snyrtilegur og þéttur. Automobile bók Automobile bók Magnús's second sculpture book, even more adventurous in concept than Pappírsást. The original idea was to take a whole car and break down its various parts into books. Although the complete concept was never fully realized, Automobile from 1970 is a step toward that vision.

The book was made by cutting a tire and inner tube in two, then welding the tube ends together, inflating it, and gluing it into the middle of the tire. The tire served as the cover, while the inflated tube ends on each side served as the pages.

searchableContent.content: Hvískur (Whisper) Hvískur (Whisper) Whisper is one of Magnús Pálsson's plaster works from the mid-1970s that belongs to the series of works where he created objectifications of the immaterial. The work can be described as a plaster cast of a whisper. The work is an attempt to materialize communication. What Nefertiti whispered to Alexander the Great, is, as its name implies, a plaster cast of a whisper, which is made by taking a plaster cast of the space between the ear that listens and the mouth that speaks. Conceptual Execution The work represents the whispers between Alexander, lying on his back in bed, and Nefertiti, lying on her side with her face turned towards his ear, with both their heads resting on a lace pillow. Negative and Positive Space Nefertiti's lips and nose appear negative on one side, and Alexander's ear negative on the other. This underscores Magnús's consistent focus on positive and negative space. Temporal Play The conceptual playfulness is evident in the fact that Alexander and Nefertiti lived 1000 years apart. Verkinu mætti lýsa sem gifsafsteypu af hvíslinu. Verkið er tilraun til að gera samskipti áþreifanleg. Það sem Nefertíte hvíslarði að Alexander mikla, er, eins og nafnið ber með sér, afsteypa af hvíslinu. Framkvæmd Hugmyndarinnar Afsteypan er fengin með því að taka afsteypu af rýminu milli munns sem hvíslar og eyra sem hlustar. Verkið sýnir hvískur á milli Alexanders, sem liggur á bakinu í rúmi, og Nefertítí, sem liggur á hliðinni með andlitið að eyra hans, en bæði höfuðin hvíla á blúndukodda. searchableContent.title: Spenna / Suspense
searchableContent.snippet: Bookwork from 1975. In this work, the invisible is made tangible. Magnús stopped reading a thriller at the moment of highest suspense and made a pl...
searchableContent.content:
Spenna / Suspense Spenna / Suspense Bookwork from 1975. In this work, the invisible is made tangible. Magnús stopped reading a thriller at the moment of highest suspense and made a plaster cast of the open book, thereby objectifying the suspense contained within.

This work exemplifies Magnús's exploration of "negative" space - the void and the objectification of the invisible - which runs throughout his book-making practice alongside his work with sculpture as visible object.

Reference: Gunnar Harðarson, "Trönurnar fljúga - Um bókagerð íslenskra myndlistarmanna", Tímarit Máls og menningar, 1985. Bókverk frá 1975. Hér er hið ósýnilega hlutgert á þann hátt að Magnús hætti að lesa spennandi reyfara þegar spennan stóð sem hæst og tók gísmót af opnu bókarinnar sem hlutgerði þannig spennuna í bókinni.

Þetta verk er dæmi um umfjöllun Magnúsar um „negatíft" rúm eða tómarúm og hlutgerving hins ósynilega, sem tengist bókagerð hans jafnt og vinnu hans með skúlptúr sem sýnilegan hlut.

searchableContent.title: Sænskir sálmar / Swedish Hymns
searchableContent.snippet: Bookwork from 1975. Using the same technique as Spenna/Suspense, Magnús made a plaster cast of an open hymn book, objectifying the sound of hymns i...
searchableContent.content:
Sænskir sálmar / Swedish Hymns Sænskir sálmar / Swedish Hymns Bookwork from 1975. Using the same technique as Spenna/Suspense, Magnús made a plaster cast of an open hymn book, objectifying the sound of hymns in solid form.

This work exemplifies Magnús's exploration of "negative" space - the void and the objectification of the invisible - capturing something intangible (sound, music) in sculptural form.

Reference: Gunnar Harðarson, "Trönurnar fljúga - Um bókagerð íslenskra myndlistarmanna", Tímarit Máls og menningar, 1985. Bókverk frá 1975. Magnús notaði sömu tækni og í Spennu/Suspense og tók gísmót af opinni sálmabók og hlutgerði þannig hljóð sálmanna í föstu formi.

Þetta verk er dæmi um umfjöllun Magnúsar um „negatíft" rúm eða tómarúm og hlutgerving hins ósynilega - að fanga eitthvað óáþreifanlegt (hljóð, tónlist) í skúlptúrformi.
